<P>Greetings fellow researchers, </P>
<P>If you're lucky enough to own a 'h=
acked' older Radio Shack 12-470, you may be in for a surprise after the TV =
signals go from analog to digital. <BR>The current TV band audio is current=
ly being broadcast in analog format. The 12-470 has a TV audio band segment=
, which now when hacked sweeps the TV audio in your area. <BR>After the sta=
tions stop broadcasting their analog signals, 12-470 owners may have an add=
itional opportunity to be able to sweep the following frequencies, with no =
interference from those high powered signals. </P>
<P>Channel - Audio Frequ=
ency <BR>2 - 59.75 MHz <BR>3 - 65.75 MHz <BR>4 - 71.75 MHz <BR>5 - 81.75 MH=
z <BR>6 - 87.75 MHz <BR>7 - 179.75 MHz <BR>8 - 185.75 MHz <BR>9 - 191.75 MH=
z <BR>10 - 197.75 MHz <BR>11 - 203.75 MHz <BR>12 - 209.75 MHz <BR>13 - 215.=
75 MHz </P>
<P>Who knows what type of signals we may be able to hear when t=
hese frequencies are open and clear. This could also provide an opportunity=
 to produce some additional experimental devices for that region of the ban=
d. Some good ghost box type experiments! </P>
<P>And as an added bonus... f=
or those interested in ITC video, just think of the opportunities that will=
 be available for you when all those TV channels have no signal. That too o=
pens up a wealth of possibilities. Lots of available white noise and empty =
video patterns for ITC research on more unused channels, without having the=
 worry of adjacent channel interference. </P>
<P>Ahh... paranormal research=
 life will be even better! </P>
